title: State of the technical infrastructure
segmentation: Good afternoon, my beloved worshippers of the Church of the Holy Clarin.
I'm very glad today to be able to preach you on the Gospel of technology.
And as always we have short time span, but there's a lot that has happened even at this very moment.
And I hope to give you a bit of highlights.

I mean, there's no way that I can show you everything that has happened in the fields of technical infrastructure, but I hope that when you leave the conference today that you can go home with at least kind of idea of all the exciting things that have happened and for most of the things to which I will be referring, you can also explore it out yourself online on the client website on the many applications that are connect.
So yeah, no worries about that.

Good, I'll start off with an overview of the technical infrastructure highlights this kind of traditional part of my talk, but still it's important because we buy coming back to this every year, we can see how the progress is given shape and gives you a bit of an idea of how Clarin has grown over the past couple of years.
To yeah, I would say mature and robust research infrastructure and I'll give you some numbers to give an idea about.
Very important part in our infrastructure are the centers.
These are really the notes in the network that are providing the resources.
The tools do.
Now.
How can one part of our centers is the certification procedure?
So for our so called B centers we have for elaborate certification procedure that exists first of all of going through the court restil assessment.
That's an external assessment and then Secondly there is our.
Assessment Committee who is doing checks to make sure that in addition to those requirements, you're also claren compatible, so to say.
And in the last year.
So since presentation in September 2018, we've had one newbie center in Estonia.
That's Clr and we have 9 centers that were successfully reassessed.
So that's whole list.
You can see it here, but it's a sphere like see baby in Berlin tubing in.
It's the ideas in Mannheim Stuttgart.
It's our colleagues from Linden Prak.
It's the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics in the Netherlands.
It's University.
Copenhagen, Denmark and its University of.
Decide on this in Sambuca.
This might seem very obvious, like oh God, they've all gone through a reassessment.
But talk to your colleagues who have done this.
It's not so obvious as it sounds.
It's really requires a lot of preparation.
Also, kind of discussion with the people from court Recil.
I mean, it's A kind of whole, quite elaborate exercise to do this.
At this moment, there's still seven more assessments pending, and it's largely because people are going through the court wrist seal procedure that takes awhile.
It can take up to 12 months or so before you.
Finish that because it requires a bit of interaction with reviewers.
Overall, that brings the number of certified centers to 22, and that's overall over a total of 57 registered centers, so 22 of those have this certified status.

Does this kind of the base layer, from which in Clarion we can work very important, not very visible, I mean specially the certification procedure might be something you're not daily involved with, but this ensures that, for instance, the centers.
Are compatible in terms of the technology and the API is the protocols the persistent identifiers that Clarin is supporting?
Good then we have the Federated login.
This is the system that allows you to use your University credentials to access services elsewhere and there.
We have extended our so called service provider Federation with the two 2 new members or observers that have joined at first of all South Africa.
So the South African academic community can also log in to Clarence services.
And it's also Cyprus smaller but also relevant because they joined as.

As a country and as a member this year, that brings the total number of organizations that can do this Federated login to 18170, and on average there's something like 2080 logins per month that are taking place for our Central discovery service.
That's not a complete number because people are not every clearance center is using this discovery service, but it's a minimum number.
And we've also had successfully operate of declare an identity provider.
Again some technicality, but it will pave the way for future improvements.

We know that in the procedure of getting a claren account, for instance, for those who are not lucky to be in one of these one 818 hundred 70 institutions, certain things can be optimized and we can work on that based on the new version of the identity provider.
Then we.
The Virtual language Observatory.
There were two new releases that brought some improvements in terms of dealing with.
First of all, the amount of records that are in there.

If you look at it today, it's about a million metadata records that are in there and through the collapsing of similar records it allows you to browse more efficiently through a long list of resources and thus hopefully to enable you to find your the thing you're looking for more quickly and efficiently.
There's also link checking.
I'll come back to that important because if you're clicking on one of those links in the vlog, you prefer also to end up somewhere with that that makes sense and not at a broken link.
And there's also a better visibility of the contributing centers if you go now in the vlog, click on contribution contributors.

You will find an explicit list of all the centers that have provided metadata to the vlog, and I think it's a very important thing to have that people who are making the efforts of making their resources available through Clarence should also get the right credits for that.
We have the curation module.
This is against some of these services are a bit at the background to give a bit of an idea.
This is the kind of technical environment where you can check the metadata quality and a set.
I mean, this is really something that we needed badly because we have now about what is at 900,000 metadata records.
This is not at the scale anymore where you can do manual checks so therefore and specially things therefore to colleagues in Vienna who have championed the creation module.
A solution for fosston complete overview of the metadata and also giving a bit of insight in the metadata provided by the individual centers.

Not so much to give them a good or a bad report, but to give them some insight in what can be improved, and especially also as a kind of analytic tool in case, for instance things don't show up correctly in the vlog.

Then you can go to the Creation Mail to understand this and in that respect it's interesting to now also that the Assessment Committee is actually actively using the curation modules, so where they used to do sampling, you look at three.
Example metadata records.
You now can select report on 10,000 metadata files and this is much more telling summary of of the metadata provided by the centers.
If you are curious, go to Claire and not useless curation and have a look around yourself.

A second bioeffects of the updates of the curation module is improved link checking statistics, and if you now go to the vlog and you see either an exclamation mark or a kind of a look there, that means that the link has been checked by the creation model by the link checker that is built in and that either the file is probably behind broken link or that there is some problem or not.
A problem that you need to authenticate to get to access through that very specific resource.
Again, it's A kind of additional service.
I'll come back to that later.
We have the content search.
There's a new version of the protocol that has been released.
There's a new content search engine, this made that's made available.
There's some new endpoints at the Institute of the Dutch language, an RLC for Clarin colleagues and pizza, and overall.
And this might be a bit technical, but we see a kind of migration from the verse version of the protocol to the second version of the protocol.
It takes awhile, but are now more or less health.
Also, nine centers have the first version.
Nine centers have the second version.
And this is taken up quite well.
It's good to see that.
We have also had a new version of the Virtual Collection Registry.
Again, you can look it up yourself on the client website where it comes with an improved interface and it comes with better connectivity to the language resource switchboards.
And that brings me to the switch boards on which I think this year there has been really a lot of work done.
Special things here to a manual Dima who has made huge efforts of making sure that the back end was basically made more stable.
And partially re engineered.

There's also been integration with some other infrastructure, so with the EU, that beta drop platform, I mean it was already there, but it was improved somehow and there's also a connection to the party, mostly for science theory.
What is actually also interesting about?
I would like to show to you today is that also there is now a better with a new front end.
So where it was looking basically as before but the back end changed.
We have now a new user interface for the battle Switchboard and I'll just give you a quick demonstration.
I hope everything works out well, but it should be OK.
So this is the new interface.
Basically it's it's made really to be very simple, so if you have say some resource that you want to process, it should take a few clicks and that's really how it is working now so I can just.
Upload the file or click here.
Have a small example file on the free room in which we are today automatically detects that this is a text file that it's in German and it gives me all the tools that can process with this.
Now if I'm a bit confused and I just want to search for the dependency parsers, then I can just restrict it with this on the fly.
Search box and I can start the tools from here so I can see that in this case we have choice between three different tools that are connected.
I can just start 'em all in parallel and for instance here I can say OK I want to run web lists.
I have Eudy pipe from from Charles University here.
You already have the results in different forms.
A table or tree.
Then we have some other spacy based dependency parser.
Here we already have the result, so it's basically allows you very quickly to fire up some tools and also to find out what kind of tools there are for your task.
And this is just obviously one of the first steps in that.
Aspect because we hope that now with both stable backends, more user friendly front end will be able to convince more of you to connect more tools to this switchboard.
It's not that hard.
It's really not a huge work to connect it and it improves very much the visibility also of your tools.
So if you're interested either for testing it, please have a look.
Better- switchboard dot Clarin dot U and if you have feedback either on the user interface or on connecting tool to it.
Please contact us as switchboard at Clarin dot EU.
Good bit of information about the back end of the infrastructure.
We keep statistics for our central services or the central services are visible to the outside world and over the last year the average uptime was 99.84%.
That's slightly less than last year and it's mainly related to one specific server that was down for some weeks during the summer.
Vacation was related to renovation also of a specific Learning Center.
And very unfortunate combination of circumstances that has been dealt with and for the future.
I've been told that this will not not happen, but still I think with such a percentage we can state that we have a fairly robust and available infrastructure.

There's also a lot of things that have been happening on central monitoring and logging level because we will have quite a few service out there now with with some things and the keywords here are flew in the Kibana Elasticsearch.
I won't bother you too much, but we now have better insight into looks, so it allows us to do quick analysis at the moment that something wrong happens or that some strange behavior is shown.
We can quickly go through the logs and see what the cause of the problem is.
Also, some improvements to the geographically redundant setup.
Now in place.
So even if a plane crashes on some of our computers centers, it should take B, so the services should remain in place.
So that's also a good thing to to know.

We've been looking into codes based security scans, so just trying to find out if there are well known security exploits in the software that we're running and finally and something quite relevant it has happened is an upgrade of our monitoring setup with Eissinger, and here I have to think the colleagues from.
From a light switch again, especially Alexander, Nathaniel and Dick and Thomas for.

Setting up completing new version of our monitoring infrastructure and this allows us very quickly to see where problems are to interact with the centers and also yourself as a center will get a notification by email in case something is wrong.
Now this I realized that this notification the Last Post days was a bit active so some of you might have been receiving lots of emails.
We found out the cause of that and that should have been stopped now and we will make sure that it comes back at a more reasonable pace so that.

You're not spammed by our monitoring, but still I think it's very important to have this kind of feedback loop because often parts of services are unavailable an if the maintainers themselves are not aware about this, then there's obviously problem.
This is some other insight.
In one of these dashboards that we have.

It allows you to quickly see where the action is going, and you know which service are under heavy loads, and I think in this case it's just showing that the website is visited a lot during the annual conference.
Well, it's not really a sub.

Price good, look at the other side of the bridge so bridging declare an infrastructure with the rest of the wild universe is maybe a bit were big word, but of the rest of the infrastructure landscape.

Ask.

There's some more information, there's videos, there's papers.
There are some guidelines.
Please have a look and the next time when you have a colleague or someone else asking also how fair is klarin?
Remember Clarin dot EU slash fair and you should have some good stories about it.
Goods last thing I would like to highlight in the connection to the outer world is our ties to the cultural heritage domain.
An here too.

There's now quite some data out there that you can for instance also process with the language resource Switchboard.
And us with acclarent tools.
That's really nice there few blocks about this.

You will see how you can use Claire and tools to process, for instance a political pamphlet here that comes from Ireland and how you can analyze such datasets.
Really nice examples.
Good so far for the traditional updates.
What's also always nice at this opportunity is that I can try to give you some insight in things that have been happening behind the scenes.
I mean technology and the infrastructure.
It sounds sometimes boring, but every year there's some exciting things that are happening, an up which I'm happy to be able to share some insights with you.
So this year.

Give you a bit of insight in some experiments that we've run with the resource families, guess you're all aware about about them about the links that are going to the resource is mentioned in the resource families, so we did some small experiment in June with all the then published resource families.
The AIDS that are depicted here on the on the right hand side in total good for about 1000 links.
And we found out that we wrote some scripts and some some little automated checks.
We found out that about 2% of those links, so about 20 links were actually not working or broken.
We contacted 10 different people's kind of follow up action to this to find out.
OK, what's the story behind this broken link?
To understand what led to that?
And actually the this conversation so gave very good insight in the kind of dynamics that can happen behind such simple thing as a link.
Explain you in a minute how that.
How to this?
Overall, there are several reasons for broken links.
One of them were basically the more technical causes and one of the technical courses that you can have is maintenance.
OK, temporary maintenance can be announced to check it later on, and the link was working again.
That's fairly straightforward, but we also find out that that actually for the most links that were not working as.
Persistent identifier that there were technical issues.
This is quite an interesting observation.
Giving in quoting some of the reactions here.

So for instance there were problems between the handle server and the database, or there was a misconfiguration of the firewall so that the handle server was not iaccessible someone had a DUI for a landing page, but that was pointing to page which was not accessible because the machine on which it was running at a full hard disk.
And Fortunately I mean with such technical.
Annoyances things can be fixed relatively quickly.
I mean, it's just a matter of reconnecting into the database server, making sure there's enough disk space, something else.
So in such situations the solution was also provided quite quickly, and I think it's interesting in such a way that it shows that the persistent identifiers there, not 100% foolproof.
I mean, even if you have a persistent identifier, you still need to make sure that the repository providing the data is still still working, so it's not the kind of Golden Boot, but at least.
If some problem occurs, it seems to be mostly of technical nature, and it can be solved relatively straightforwardly.
Another category word.
Real changes where we had links to.
For instance project pages.
And that's something we cannot avoid when in the resource families.

Sometimes you want to give some more information than just a link to a data set, so you also have linked to project or some landing page and some of the answers that we got there are for instance, well, OK, our corpus project page now has a new URL, should be using that one or our data set is available at another sub domain.
So yeah.
You need to update your URL or that server apparently has been discontinued.
The data is still available, but you have to look in a repository.
And what was interesting to see here?
I mean, there were more stories about this, but this gives a bit of an ID.
Is that URL change often seems to reflect the kind of organizational change, and as such it's unavoidable.
I mean, it's a logical thing.
Universities, structures, projects, they change overtime.

So obviously in such cases the URL where you often can find information about the project, which is often not directly connected to persist identifier, also needs to be changed and interesting side observation.
There was also that the interaction.
With the resource providers elites quite unexpectedly for me too, improvements of the description.
So by having an interaction with the resource providers asking OK, do you have a better URL on this?

Because this is broken they came with OK, but I looked and actually there's still some mistake here or we have a new corpus here, so can you also please edit so it proved that this kind of interaction was actually very valuable.
I found that very interesting.
Yeah, lesson from this.
Summing up on the on the link checking, I think automated link checking is really, really important.
We've grown to a level.
If you look at the number of links in the vlog you kept up to 7 million links or so, I think that is completely impossible to check manually.
So we need automated checks for this.
Following up on broken links and on issues found.
It's not only on broken links, take some time, but it's a good investment since improvements.
On those links can also have a broader impact.

They can often fix lots of hidden technical issues, the firewalls, the disks, whatever, and also they lead to better metadata because you're asking people who were providing the information to have seconds more critical look on it and they see something and they can contribute something.
So I think All in all, it's not an easy thing to do, but it's definitely something that we as a community need to do to make sure that we follow up on the curation of those.
Yeah, those metadata entries and I think this team is also relevant at a broader scale and now specifically thinking at European Open Science Cloud.
I mean, we've had similar discussions in the context of the shock marketplace that we were discussing about.
So this is something that will come back.

And where I hope that we can also play a role in connecting our know how and technology that we have with more generally applicable technology and services for infrastructures and for the European Open science clouds.
Good stats brings me to the end of my presentation, but not without.

Shining spotlights on the people who really did the hard work because for me it's easy to go over all the results of the year, but you should really realize that everything that has been mentioned here today is only possible because of the many hours that people have been coding, debugging, cursing and in the end also fixing problems that were around there and improving infrastructural services.
And well, I will at least mention here the assessment Committee because they have done the hard work of going through the evaluation of all the.
Clarence enters the central developer team.
The developers from the national consortia and also all the task forces.
There are many names here.

Thank you very much.
Questions remarks.
Also, if there are any questions.
Or everything runs so smoothly.
Detour, you know, no questions needed.
Thank you very much and also thanks of course to everybody who's collaborating on the.
Improvement of the technical infrastructure.
I have a question about that slide you showed about monitoring which looks quite interesting.
Also as a system in general we always look at ways of better, more into our system and I wonder what are those #4.
So when you talk about hosts, what does that mean?
And when you talk about service, could you say a bit more?
Thank you.
The exact numbers are here on the down part of the of the slide.
The host is really seen as the physical server, so whether a machine is reachable or not, services.
Can be multiple services running on a single server.
The reason why the number is relatively high here is that it's just because our colleagues in life see actually not done Elvis extremely fast with implementing a feature that we requested.
So we found out that we actually would like to monitor the availability of the services that are included in the language resource switchboards and well, we made an issue of that.
We posted it and we told well it would be nice to have and one day later we already had to check Nathaniel Fick.

Connected it to the metadata Store for for the switchboards and it also meant that certain development services which were not shown in the production version were immediately detected as not being out there or having an issue.

And that is one of the reasons why the number here is relatively relatively high, but in a way it's also good because then we have something to take up with the centers who are providing the services and sometimes there are also minor things.
I mean, sometimes you know I PMH endpoint.
Is delivering invalid XML, but the harvesting still works.
So then it's a kind of a. I wouldn't say false alert, but the kind of superficial alert.
So but actually following up on this that is also against something that takes a bit of effort.
I mean it's in the same category as following up on the broken links.
Its first finding out what the report is about contacting the responsible person at the center and then together trying to find out what is actually causing this problem and trying to fixing it.
And it's quite a bit of effort, I mean specially in summer months we've been.

Going through a backlog of reports that we have had and I have to say that in most cases things were picked up quite quickly, but it's good to have some kind of central to do keeper of seeing what kind of issues there, and sometimes contacting the centers asking how have you been able to look into that as a kind of reminder, and as such that has been working quite well.
And that's also why I'm happy why we now have the even improved system with checks for the switchboard.
OK.
I don't see any more hands race, so I think we thank teacher again and thank you very much all the teams.
And I.
